Comment: Adjectives are not a distinct part of speech in Lakota. They are merely a subset of the class of stative verbs.
They can also be placed prenominally (wakˇh´aN-wiˇch´aˇsa kiN ‘the holy (type of) man’), but this construction involves compounding, unlikethe postnominal one.
Must be coverted to a RC. THINK WHERE TO PUT THE INFO ON RELATIVE CLAUSES. Requires the presence of a set of determiners (as nominalizers), see p.47 in van Valin Jr. (1977).
Such constructions require the presence of locative prefixes.
lkt is a consistently left-branching language (see p.40 in Ullrich,)

ID: No stacking possible because lkt is consistently left-branching.
